case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Madan Mohan Nagar

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 997 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 997 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 25, 1963 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 431 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 431 of 1962.

facts.text: Shri Madan Mohan Nagar filed Writ Petition in Allahabad High Court to quash compulsory retirement order dated July 28, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, C. B. Agarwala and O. P. Rana, for the appellant. P. Goyal and B. P. Jha, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was deliv

facts.text: Compulsory retirement order dated July 28, 1960 against Madan Mohan Nagar, Director State Museum Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Shri Madan Mohan Nagar, filed a Writ Petition in the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad for quashing the order of companypulsory retirement dated July 28, 1960, passed against him.

facts.text: Order stated Governor pleased to order compulsory retirement with effect from September 1, 1960 under Article 465A Note 1 CSR as outlived utility.

anchor.surface_text: The order of companypulsory retirement was in the following terms I am directed to say that the Governor has been pleased to order in the public interest under Article 465A and Note 1  thereof of the Civil Service Regulations, the companypulsory retirement with effect from September 1, 1960 of Sri Madan Mohan Nagar, Director State Museum Lucknow who companypleted 52 years of age on July 1, 1960, and 28 years and .3 months of qualifying service on 31-5-1960 as he has outlived his utility.

facts.text: Madan Mohan Nagar completed 52 years of age on July 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: who companypleted 52 years of age on July 1, 1960, and 28 years and .3 months of qualifying service on 31-5-1960 as he has outlived his utility.

facts.text: Madan Mohan Nagar had 28 years and 3 months qualifying service on May 31, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: and 28 years and .3 months of qualifying service on 31-5-1960 as he has outlived his utility.

facts.text: Learned Single Judge quashed the order holding Rule 465 CSR violates Article 16(1) and violation of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge who heard the petition quashed the order on the ground that Rule 465 of the Civil Service Regulations as amended by the U.P. Government while providing a criterion for the guidance of Government when inflicting companypulsory retirement on a government servant nevertheless violates the guarantee of equality of opportunity in matters relating to employment under Article 16 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Division Bench upheld Single Judge order on ground violation of Article 311.

anchor.surface_text: The State appealed and the Division Bench on appeal upheld the order passed by the learned Single Judge on the ground that the order of companypulsory retirement was passed in violation of the provisions of art. 311 of the Constitution and was, therefore, ultra vires.

facts.text: State obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State having obtained special leave, the appeal is number before us.

facts.text: No enquiry as contemplated by Article 311(2) was held. Common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that numberenquiry as companytemplated by Art. 311 2  was held.

facts.text: Respondent first appointed in 1931 on one year probation as Custodian, Sarnath Museum, Banaras, under Archaeological Department of Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: The facts, in brief, are that the respondent was first appointed in 1931 on one years probation to the post of Custodian, Sarnath Museum, Banaras, under the Archaeological Department of the Government of India.

facts.text: In 1939, respondent posted to Mathura Museum as Curator.

anchor.surface_text: In 1939, he was posted to Mathura Museum as Curator,

facts.text: Respondent appointed substantively to Curator Mathura from January 5, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: and he was appointed substantively to this post from January 5, 1941.

facts.text: Respondent appointed on recommendation of Provincial Public Service Commission as Curator State Museum Lucknow on scale Rs. 250-850.

anchor.surface_text: Later, he was appointed on the recommendation of the Provincial Public Service companymission as Curator of the State Museum, Lucknow, on a scale of pay Rs. 250/- to Rs. 850/-

facts.text: Post of Curator upgraded to Director State Museum Lucknow in U.P. Educational Service Senior Scale, respondent appointed to it.

anchor.surface_text: . The post of Curator was upgraded to the post of Director, State Museum, Lucknow, in the U.P. Educational Service, Senior Scale, and the respondent was appointed to it.

facts.text: Respondent continued in service as Director State Museum Lucknow until compulsorily retired by order dated July 28, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the respondent companytinued in service as Director of State Museum, Lucknow, until he was companypulsorily retired by the order of the Government, dated July 28, 1960, which has already been set out above.

facts.text: Article 465A CSR allows retirement after 25 years qualifying service in public interest if outlived usefulness.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of Article 465A of the Civil Service Regulation is in the following terms Government retains the right to retire any Government servant after he has companypleted 25 years qualifying service without giving any reasons, and numberclaim to special companypensation on this account shall be entertained. This right shall only be exercised by Government in the Administrative Department when it is in the public interest to dispense with the services of Government servant who has outlived his usefulness.

facts.text: Compulsory retirement order states respondent outlived his utility.

anchor.surface_text: the fact that the impugned order of companypulsory retirement states the reason for companypulsory retirement, namely, that the respondent had outlived his utility,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds the order casts stigma on respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this case is companyered by the principle applied in Jagdish Mitter v. Union of India  2 . It is true that that was a case of a temporary servant, but that does number matter. The order  1  1955 1 S. C. R.26.

facts.text: No departmental enquiry held before retirement order.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that numberenquiry as companytemplated by Art. 311 2  was held.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Full Bench in Abdul Ahad case overruled Division Bench under appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor General also brought to our numberice the decision of the Full Bench of the Allahabad High Court in Abdul Ahad v. The Inspector General of Police, U.P.  4  The decision ,certainly helps him, and as a matter of fact, the Full Bench overruled the judgment of the Division Bench under appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this case is companyered by the principle applied in Jagdish Mitter v. Union of India  2 . ... The test in such cases must be does the order cast aspersion or attach stigma to the officer when it purports to discharge him? If the answer to this question is in the affirmative, then numberwithstanding the form of the order, the termination of service must be held, in substance, to amount to dismissal.

concepts.interpretation: Same test applies to compulsory retirement: if order casts aspersion or stigma, it amounts to dismissal notwithstanding form; requires Article 311(2) compliance. Here, 'outlived his utility' casts stigma.

In the present case there is numberdoubt that the order does cast a stigma on the respondent.

arguments.claim: Order attaches stigma because states outlived utility meaning incapacitated

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is number only numberquestion of implication but a clear statement appears on the face of the order that the respondent had outlived his utility in other words, it is stated that he was incapacitated from holding the post of Director, State Museum, Lucknow. The order clearly attaches a stigma to him

arguments.claim: Cases like Balakotiah, Dalip Singh not applicable as no stigma there

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Balakotaih v. The Union of India 1  [...] In Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab 2  the order read as follows His Highness the Rajpramukh is pleased to retire from service Sardar Dalip Singh [...] It was held that the order did number amount to dismissal or removal

arguments.claim: First test from Shyam Lal: charge/imputation condition for power; here outlived utility is such charge

anchor.surface_text: If the first test is applied in this case it is quite clear that the charge or imputation that the respondent had outlived his utility was made the companydition of the ,exercise of the power.

arguments.claim: Question whether Article 465A Note 1 violates Art 311(1) not argued, so not decided

anchor.surface_text: We may say that the question whether Article 465-A, numbere  1 , violates art. 31 1 of the Constitution was number argued before us and we say numberhing about it.

holdings.text: The impugned order of compulsory retirement casts a stigma on the respondent because it expressly states that he had outlived his utility, implying incapacity.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is not only no question of implication but a clear statement appears on the face of the order that the respondent had outlived his utility in other words, it is stated that he was incapacitated from holding the post of Director, State Museum, Lucknow. The order clearly attaches a stigma to him and any person who reads the order would immediately consider that there is something wrong with him or his capacity to work.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express statement on face of order implies incapacity, unlike implied in routine compulsory retirements; any reader would infer something wrong with capacity.

holdings.text: The same stigma test applied in Jagdish Mitter v. Union of India applies to compulsory retirement orders: if the order casts aspersion or attaches stigma, it amounts to dismissal notwithstanding its form.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this case is covered by the principle applied in Jagdish Mitter v. Union of India. It is true that that was a case of a temporary servant, but that does not matter. ... The test in such cases must be does the order cast aspersion or attach stigma to the officer when it purports to discharge him? If the answer to this question is in the affirmative, then notwithstanding the form of the order, the termination of service must be held, in substance, to amount to dismissal. It seems to us that the same test must apply in the case of compulsory retirement...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends precedent from temporary discharge to permanent compulsory retirement; irrelevant distinction between temporary/permanent.

holdings.text: The impugned order amounts to dismissal or removal requiring compliance with Article 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is no doubt that the order does cast a stigma on the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stigma present per h1 and h2, no enquiry held (common ground), thus violates Art 311(2).

holdings.text: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh does not imply that compulsory retirement carries stigma of misbehaviour or incapacity; no imputation is condition for exercise of power under Article 465A Note 1.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to read Shyam Lals case in that manner because the Court expressly said at p. 41, as follows: It is true that this power of compulsory retirement may be used when the authority exercising this power cannot substantiate the misconduct which may be the real cause for taking the action but what is important to note is that the directions in the last sentence in Note 1 to article 465-A make it abundantly clear that an imputation or charge is not in terms made a condition for the exercise of the power. In other words, a compulsory retirement has no stigma or implication of misbehaviour or incapacity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct quote from Shyam Lal clarifies no stigma normally; distinguishes present express case.

holdings.text: The first test from Shyam Lal applies: where a charge or imputation is made the condition for exercise of compulsory retirement power, it is punitive.

anchor.surface_text: The Court derived two tests from Shyam Lals case and formulated them as follows: the first is whether the action is by way of punishment and to find that out the Court said that it was necessary that a charge or imputation against the officer is made the condition of the exercise of the power... If the first test is applied in this case it is quite clear that the charge or imputation that the respondent had outlived his utility was made the condition of the exercise of the power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Outlived utility expressly made condition here, satisfying Shyam Lal test for punishment.

holdings.text: Expressly stating that a servant has outlived his utility attaches stigma and makes position worse than mere implication.

anchor.surface_text: But, with respect, we are unable to agree with the conclusion that even if the order of compulsory retirement recites the fact that the public servant had outlived his utility, it would not amount to a punitive order... We are unable to agree that the position does not become worse because a stigma is attached expressly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects Abdul Ahad Full Bench; express stigma worsens case vs implied.

holdings.text: The question whether Article 465A Note 1 violates Article 311(1) was not argued and is not decided.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not argued before the court.

precedents.citation: Shyam Lal v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Shyam Lal v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 and says that in that case it was implied that Shyam Lal was number fit to be retained in service. We are unable to read Shyam Lals case 1 in that manner because the Court expressly said at p. 41, as follows It is true that this power of companypulsory retirement may be used when the authority exercising this power cannot substantiate the misconduct which may be the real cause for taking the action but what is important to numbere is that the directions in the last sentence in Note 1 to article 465-A make it abundantly clear that an imputation or charge is number in terms made a companydition for the exercise of the power.

precedents.case_name: Shyam Lal v State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Compulsory retirement under Article 465A does not imply misconduct or incapacity and carries no stigma
precedents.cited_holding: a compulsory retirement has no stigma or implication of misbehaviour or incapacity

anchor.surface_text: Jagdish Mitter v. Union of India  2 . It is true that that was a case of a temporary servant, but that does number matter. The order  1  1955 1 S. C. R.26. A. I. R. 1964 S.C.449 in that case reads as follows Shri Jagdish Mitter, a temporary 2nd Division Clerk of this office having been found undesirable to be retained in Government service is hereby served with a months numberice of discharge with effect from November 1, 1949.

precedents.case_name: Jagdish Mitter v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: An order of termination that casts a stigma or aspersion amounts to dismissal even if purporting to be discharge
precedents.cited_holding: when the order refers to the fact that the appellant was found undesirable to be retained in government service, it expressly casts a stigma on the appellant and ... must be held to be an order of dismissal

anchor.surface_text: Moti Ram Deka v. N. E. Frontier Railway 2 . We will presently companysider the effect of the decision in Dekas case. In Dekas case 2  Moti Ram Deka, who was a peon employed by the North East Frontier Railway, challenged the order of termination of his services under Rule 148 of the Indian Railway Establishment Code on the ground that the said Rule was invalid the validity of Rule 149 of the Railway Establishment Code.

Union of India 3 , in respect of permanent government servants in preference to that accepted in shyam Lals case 4  and the subsequent decisions following it. But it is number necessary for us to resolve the companyflict, if any, which exists between Dhingras case 3  and Shyam Lals case 4  because here we have an order which on the face of its casts a stigma on the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: State of Bombay v., Saubhagchand, M. Doshi 5  Rule 165-A of the Bombay Civil Services Rules laid down that the right of, companypulsory retirement will number be exercised except when it is in the public interest to dispense with the further services of a Government servant such as on account of inefficiency or dishonesty, but in Doshis case it does number appear that the order companytained any aspersion that Doshi was inefficient or suffered from some other defect.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v Saubhagchand M Doshi
precedents.cited_proposition: Rule allowing compulsory retirement for inefficiency etc does not violate Art 311(2) if order contains no stigma

precedents.citation: Balakotaih v. The Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: Balakotaih v. The Union of India 1  in Rule 3 ,of the Railway Services  Safeguarding of National Security  Rules, 1949, dealing with companypulsory retirement, the proviso provided that a member of the Railway Service shall number be retired or have his service so terminated unless the companypetent authority is satisfied that his retention in public serice is prejudical to national security,

precedents.cited_proposition: Compulsory retirement under rules requiring satisfaction of prejudice to security, without stigma in order

precedents.citation: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab 2

anchor.surface_text: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab 2  the order read as follows His Highness the Rajpramukh is pleased to retire from service Sardar Dalip Singh, Inspector General of Police, Pepsu  on leave  for administrative reasons with effect from the 18th August 1950. anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is not only no question of implication but a clear statement appears on the face of the order that the respondent had outlived his utility in other words, it is stated that he was incapacitated from holding the post of Director, State Museum, Lucknow. The order clearly attaches a stigma to him and any person who reads the order would immediately consider that there is something wrong with him or his capacity to work.

In the present case there is not only no question of implication but a clear statement appears on the face of the order that the respondent had outlived his utility in other words, it is stated that he was incapacitated from holding the post of Director, State Museum, Lucknow. anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this case is covered by the principle applied in Jagdish Mitter v. Union of India. It is true that that was a case of a temporary servant, but that does not matter. ... The test in such cases must be does the order cast aspersion or attach stigma to the officer when it purports to discharge him? If the answer to this question is in the affirmative, then notwithstanding the form of the order, the termination of service must be held, in substance, to amount to dismissal. It seems to us that the same test must apply in the case of compulsory retirement...

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this case is covered by the principle applied in Jagdish Mitter v. Union of India. The test in such cases must be does the order cast aspersion or attach stigma to the officer when it purports to discharge him? If the answer to this question is in the affirmative, then notwithstanding the form of the order, the termination of service must be held, in substance, to amount to dismissal. It seems to us that the same test must apply in the case of compulsory retirement...

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is no doubt that the order does cast a stigma on the respondent.
In the present case there is no doubt that the order does cast a stigma on the respondent.

We are unable to read Shyam Lals case in that manner because the Court expressly said at p. 41, as follows: It is true that this power of compulsory retirement may be used when the authority exercising this power cannot substantiate the misconduct which may be the real cause for taking the action but what is important to note is that the directions in the last sentence in Note 1 to article 465-A make it abundantly clear that an imputation or charge is not in terms made a condition for the exercise of the power. In other words, a compulsory retirement has no stigma or implication of misbehaviour or incapacity.
e within the meaning of art. 311 2  of the Constitution. The Court derived two tests from Shyam Lals case 3  and formulated them as follows the first

anchor.surface_text: e within the meaning of art. 311 2  of the Constitution. The Court derived two tests from Shyam Lals case 3  and formulated them as follows the first

anchor.surface_text: The Court derived two tests from Shyam Lals case and formulated them as follows: the first is whether the action is by way of punishment and to find that out the Court said that it was necessary that a charge or imputation against the officer is made the condition of the exercise of the power... If the first test is applied in this case it is quite clear that the charge or imputation that the respondent had outlived his utility was made the condition of the exercise of the power.

The Court derived two tests from Shyam Lals case and formulated them as follows: the first is whether the action is by way of punishment and to find that out the Court said that it was necessary that a charge or imputation against the officer is made the condition of the exercise of the power... If the first test is applied in this case it is quite clear that the charge or imputation that the respondent had outlived his utility was made the condition of the exercise of the power.

But, with respect, we are unable to agree with the conclusion that even if the order of compulsory retirement recites the fact that the public servant had outlived his utility, it would not amount to a punitive order... We are unable to agree that the position does not become worse because a stigma is attached expressly.
